FACILITY AND INVESTMENT PROGRAM SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  People’s Republic of China (PRC) 
   
Classification  Targeting classification: General intervention 
Sector  (subsector):  Transport,  and  information  and 
communication technology (rail transport) 
Themes (subthemes): Economic  growth (promoting economic 
efficiency and enabling business environment, widening access to 
markets  and  economic  opportunities),  environmental 
sustainability, capacity development 
Location impact: Rural (high), urban (medium), national (high) 
   
Safeguard Assessment  A safeguard framework has been prepared for the Railway Energy 
Efficiency and Safety Enhancement Investment Program. The first 
tranche is classified category C for all safeguards in accordance 
with this framework. 
   
Investment Program  The  investment  program  is  the  first  targeted  intervention  to 
Description  promote energy efficiency, improve environmental sustainability, 
and  improve  safety  in  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB) 
transport sector operations and in the PRC transport sector. This 
will  be  implemented  on  the  PRC  railway  network  in  the 
southwestern PRC—a poor and underserved area of the PRC 
consisting of Guangxi, Guizhou, Sichuan, and Yunnan provinces, 
and Chongqing Municipality—over the next 7 years (2009–2016). 
The investment program is a priority investment included in the 
Eleventh Five-Year Plan of the Government, 2006–2010, and the 
stimulus package announced in October 2008. 
   
Multitranche Financing  This  is  the  first  time  the  multitranche  financing  facility  (MFF) 
Facility  modality will be used in the PRC transport sector. The investment 
program will be implemented in the less developed southwestern 
region, an area that is supported by ADB, and will form a part of 
the  government’s  railway  development  plan  and  its  stimulus 
package. Options for possible financing modalities were explored. 
The use of the MFF modality is considered the most appropriate 
for financing this investment program given the need to finance 
multiple projects under an investment program, provide flexible 
tranche financing requirements to suit the readiness of individual 
projects, have long-term engagement; and the strong institutional 
capacity of the Ministry of Railways (MOR), the executing agency. 
The proposed MFF provides flexibility to the government and to 
ADB. Since the development plan will be implemented over the 
next 7 years, the government can submit the periodic financing 
request  (PFR)  when  the  projects  are  ready  to  use  these 
equipment  and  materials;  and  this  can  be  matched  with  the 
availability of funds on the ADB side. The framework approach 
provided  an  opportunity  for  streamlining  domestic  procedures. 
The  investment  program,  to  be  implemented  over  the  next  7 
years,  reflects  a  medium-  to  long-term  engagement.  The

ii   
investments will be supported by a sustained medium-term policy 
dialogue in the areas of improving energy efficiency, enhancing 
railway  safety,  enhancing  environmental  sustainability,  and 
capacity development. These will be supported by providing a 
technical assistance (TA) grant. 
   
Rationale  MOR will implement a plan for railway development (2009–2016) 
at a cost of about $25 billion for capacity expansion over the 
southwestern region of the PRC. This includes activities such as 
new  construction,  double  tracking,  electrification,  and 
rehabilitation. Within this plan, one option was to support railway 
construction or capacity expansion as has been done in the past 
and another option was to support targeted areas such as energy 
efficiency,  environmental  sustainability,  and  safety,  which  are 
critically important areas for PRC railway sector and where ADB’s 
contribution could be clearly distinguished. Within this plan, ADB 
identified an investment program of $3.24 billion to support these 
three areas, for which it will provide support of $1 billion through 
the proposed MFF. The cost of the equipment is small compared 
to the cost of other capital assets or construction of a railway line, 
but their benefits are significant and it is easy to integrate them 
when the government is implementing the development plan. This 
would  have  high  value  added  with  a  smaller  investment, 
leveraging much more value addition. 
 
  The proposed investment program is consistent with two of the 
four pillars of ADB’s country partnership strategy for the PRC: 
(i) inclusive growth and balanced development, and (ii) resource 
efficiency  and  environmental  sustainability.  The  investment 
program  reflects  (i)  network  development,  which  will  enhance 
capacity and reduce bottlenecks; (ii) improved energy efficiency 
and environmental sustainability by providing a more efficient and 
environment-friendly  mode  of  transport  in  the  southwestern 
region; (iii) enhanced safety through the provision of a reliable and 
safe  mode  of  transport;  (iv) support  for  the  PRC  railway 
development plan and the western region development strategy; 
and  (v) promotion  of  pro-poor  economic  growth  in  the  region, 
thereby reducing poverty. The investment program will emphasize 
energy  conservation,  environmental  sustainability,  and  safety 
through the introduction of safe and reliable technology on the 
railway network, which will result in improved reliability, higher 
mobility, increased network capacity, optimal use of the network 
and assets, and increased staff productivity. All of these will lead 
to higher efficiency of the railway network.  
 
  The investment program will be implemented in the southwestern 
PRC, a relatively poor area. The region is largely mountainous 
with  abundant  natural  reserves  of  coal,  and  other  nonferrous 
materials; and famous tourist sites. In spite of abundant natural 
resources,  many  people  are  poor  and  the  economic  growth 
necessary to reduce rural poverty has been insufficient because

iii
of  inadequate  transport  services  and  high  costs.  The  railway 
density in the southwestern region is the lowest in the PRC, and 
local governments and people living in the southwestern region 
see the railway as a key investment for addressing this problem. 
Railway development is part of the government’s program for the 
integrated  development  of  transportation  facilities  in  this  poor 
region  and  MOR  plans  to  develop  6,500  kilometers  (km)  of 
railways  in  the  southwestern  region  by  2015.  The  proposed 
southwestern  region  also  shares  borders  with  Viet  Nam,  and 
Yunnan and Guangxi provinces are part of the Greater Mekong 
Subregion. The development of railways is expected to play an 
important  role  in  facilitating  and  integrating  this  poor  and 
underdeveloped  region,  and  stimulating  regional  and 
interprovincial  trade  and  movement  of  people.  The  investment 
program  is  a  priority  investment  included  in  the  government’s 
proposed Eleventh Five-Year Plan and the stimulus package. It is 
also in line with the Railway Development Plan and supports the 
government’s western region development strategy. 
   
Impact and Outcome  The  impact  of  the  proposed  investment  program  will  be  an 
improved transport system in the region that supports sustainable 
socioeconomic development and the western region development 
strategy. Providing economic railway transportation in unserved, 
less  developed,  and  poor  areas  will  create  conditions  for 
developing local resources, employment opportunities, and higher 
incomes; and thus raise living standards in the project area. The 
outcome of the investment program will be an energy-efficient, 
safe,  reliable,  affordable,  and  environment-friendly  railway 
transport system developed in the southwestern region. 
   
Investment Plan   The  tentative  program  investment  cost  is  estimated  at 
$3.24 billion, including taxes and duties. The total cost includes 
price  contingencies,  interest,  and  other  charges  during 
implementation.

Multitranche Financing  The  MFF  will  provide  up  to  $1.00  billion  from  ADB’s  ordinary 
Facility Amount and  capital resources, with final terms and conditions to be established 
Terms  under  individual  loan  agreements  based  on  prevailing  ADB 
policies. The financing will be subject to interest to be determined 
in accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate-based 
lending facility, the applicable commitment charge, and such other 
terms and conditions set forth in the related loan agreements. The 
government  has  the  flexibility  to  choose  between  eligible 
currencies and interest rate regimes most suitable for each loan. 
ADB provides flexibility in terms of repayment and interest rate 
swaps  during  the  financing  period  in  accordance  with  the 
framework  financing  agreement,  relevant  loan  regulations,  and 
draft loan agreements. Currency schedules can be structured in 
line with the specific needs of individual loans. 
   
Advance Contracting and  Because of the urgency of implementing the stimulus package, 
Retroactive Financing  the government has requested approval of advance contracting 
and retroactive financing of up to 20% of the first loan proceeds, 
for  expenditures  incurred  and  paid  for  but  not  earlier  than 
12 months before the date of the loan agreement. This request 
was approved on 9 September 2009. The government has been 
informed that provision of advance contracting and procurement 
and retroactive financing does not commit ADB to finance the 
tranches.  For  subsequent  tranches,  retroactive  financing  of 
otherwise eligible expenditures may be considered and allowed by 
ADB  Management  when  included  in  a  PFR.  Total  retroactive 
financing will not exceed an amount equivalent to 20% of the 
individual  loan  and  must  have  been  incurred  not  more  that 
12 months before the signing of the related legal agreements. 
   
Period of Utilization  The investment program will be implemented over 7 years. The 
number of PFRs will be from three to six. The disbursement of the 
first PFR is expected to be completed by 30 June 2016. The 
disbursement of the last tranche will be completed no later than 
30 June 2017. 
   
Executing Agency and  MOR  will  be  the  executing  agency  responsible  for  the  overall 
Implementation  investment  program  implementation.  The  Foreign  Capital  and 
Arrangements  Technical Import Center, under MOR, will coordinate the project 
management office’s tasks and be responsible for procurement, 
withdrawals,  and  reporting  in  relation  to  ADB.  A  steering 
committee, headed by the director general of the Foreign Capital 
and Technical Import Center, will be responsible for the selection 
of  projects  for  subsequent  financing  by  ADB,  and  their 
implementation. Staff employed will be experienced in technical, 
financial, and administrative matters; and implementing projects 
financed by international financial institutions.

v
Procurement  All procurement to be financed under the MFF ADB loan will be 
carried  out  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines 
(2007, as amended from time to time). The procurement plan for 
each tranche will be discussed and finalized during the fact-finding 
mission for the respective tranche.  
   
Project Benefits and  The  investment  program  will  (i) reduce  fuel  consumption  and 
Beneficiaries  enhance energy efficiency, enabling the PRC to save valuable 
foreign  exchange,  (ii)  improve  the  environment  and  reduce 
pollution; (iii) enhance railway safety, enabling railway users to 
benefit from lower transport costs; (iv) increase the line capacity, 
benefiting  consumers  and  producers  of  goods  and  services 
through the provision of timely and efficient transport services and 
lower logistics costs; and (v) improve staff productivity, enabling 
railway users to benefit from lower costs.  
 
  The major project beneficiaries will be (i) the government, which 
will benefit from improved safety, reduced economic losses, and a 
reduced  energy  bill;  (ii)  passengers,  who  will  benefit  from 
affordable, environment-friendly, faster, and safer trips; (iii) freight 
shippers, who will benefit from reduced damage to shipments and 
more affordable, faster, and safer trips; and (iv) private sector who 
will  benefit  from  new  business  and  job  opportunities  and 
enhanced economic competitiveness. 
 
  Railway  development  generates  job  opportunities  (skilled  and 
unskilled)  for  the  poor,  ethnic  minorities,  women,  and  other 
vulnerable  groups,  which  helps  develop  their  job  skills.  Job 
opportunities will provide potential new sources of income for local 
residents. An increase in female participation in the labor and 
tourism  market  increases  women’s  net  income  and  savings, 
improves  overall  family  welfare,  and  helps  improve  women’s 
status. Women and other vulnerable groups benefit from railway 
development and have equal access to employment and wages. 
Railway  development  generates  demand  for  local  labor  and 
increases worker productivity and wages. Expansion of secondary 
and  tertiary  industries  helps  generate  additional  employment 
opportunities for both men and women, close to their homes.  
   
Risks and Assumptions  The investment program is formulated to minimize potential risks. 
Sensitivity  tests  indicate  that  there  would  have  to  be  a  sharp 
deterioration  in  economic  circumstances  for  the  investment 
program to lose economic viability. A potential risk is delay in 
implementation,  which  would  delay  the  realization  of  benefits. 
MOR has successfully implemented ADB-financed projects. Risks 
associated with potential changes in government policy for railway 
development are minimal. An analysis of the demand for railway 
transport  shows  that  the  southwestern  PRC  needs  additional 
railway transport capacity to sustain its economic development. 
Macroeconomic conditions  are expected to continue to be sound,

vi   
  with  continuing  political  stability  in  the  PRC.  Strong  economic 
performance is expected in the southwestern PRC based on the 
government’s projections and its growth trends. 
   
The  equipment  and  materials  to  be  procured  and  included  in 
tranche  1  are  based  on  proven  and  established  technologies. 
MOR has experience of installing new technologies successfully 
and these can be implemented within a relatively short time. For 
subsequent tranches, equipment and material with similar proven 
energy efficiency, environmental benefits, and safety benefits will 
be used. Thus, the technical risks of the investment program are 
minimal.  
 
  Successful implementation requires sound project management. 
MOR  has  strong  implementation  experience  and  adequate 
capacity. The innovative design of the investment program will 
necessitate  additional  training,  and  supplemental  TA  support 
provided by ADB would further assist MOR in strengthening its 
capacity.  MOR  agreed  to  provide  counterpart  support  for  TA 
implementation. The key MOR personnel are well experienced in 
ADB project implementation.  
   
Technical Assistance  The  government  has  requested  TA  support  for  institutional 
development and enhancing staff capacity with MOR and railway 
administration. A TA grant of $600,000 from the TA Special Fund-
Others is proposed to support the government’s request. The TA 
will (i) review the existing institutional arrangements for integrating 
energy  efficiency  and  environmental  issues  in  railway 
management  and  operation,  compare  these  in  developed 
countries, identify the gaps, and make recommendations for MOR 
to  implement;  (ii) undertake  safety  and  energy  audits  of  a 
nominated  railway  administration,  identifying  areas  where 
improvements can be made; and (iii) undertake capacity building 
programs to familiarize staff and create awareness about energy 
efficiency, environmental sustainability, and safety.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
multitranche financing facility (MFF) to the People’s Republic of China (PRC) for the Railway 
Energy Efficiency and Safety Enhancement Investment Program. The report also describes 
proposed technical assistance (TA) for Institutional and Capacity Development, and if the Board 
approves the proposed investment program, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the 
Board, will approve the TA. The design and monitoring framework for the investment program is 
in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
 
2.  From 1978, when market-oriented economic reforms were introduced, through to 2008, 
the PRC has experienced sustained rapid economic growth that has resulted in a rapid increase 
in  demand  for  transportation.  Annual  growth  in  passenger  transport  was  9%  and  freight 
transport grew at 7.6% during 1978–2008. Railway is the principal mode of freight transport in 
the PRC. In 2008, the modal split for freight ton-kilometers (km) was 45.2% for railways, 
followed by 29.6% for inland waterways and seashore shipping, 21.1% for roads, 3.3% for 
pipelines,  and  0.2%  for  civil  aviation.  In  2008,  road  traffic  accounted  for  53.3%  of  total 
passenger-km, followed by railways with 33.4%, civil aviation with 12.9%, and coastal and 
inland waterways with 3.5%. 
 
3.  The railway is the primary mode of long-distance and bulk transport. At the end of 2008, 
the  PRC’s  79,700  route-km  of  railways  comprised  64,000  km  of  national  railways  and 
15,700 km of joint venture and local railways. The Ministry of Railways (MOR) runs the state-
owned national railway as an integrated system. The joint venture and local railways, regional 
lines within provincial boundaries, are built under provincial government or MOR sponsorship to 
serve local needs and interconnect with the national railway network. Despite its large size, 
however, the railway network does not provide adequate coverage for the country’s population 
and land area.1  
 
4.  PRC railways have the highest freight transport density in the world and the second 
highest passenger transport density after Japan. Locomotive turnover is the highest in the world. 
From 1978 to 2008, railway freight increased from 535 billion ton-km to 2,482 billion ton-km, or 
by 5.25% yearly, and passenger traffic grew by 6.74% yearly, from 109 billion passenger-km to 
778 billion passenger-km. For passenger trips, the average railway journey increased from 
134 km in 1978 to 536 km in 2008, compared with road travel, which grew from 35 km to 56 km 
over the same period. For freight, the average railway journey in 2008 was 778 km, compared 
with 69 km for road transport. Yet, despite such growth rates, railway capacity has lagged 
behind demand because of constraints in the system.2 Given the railway’s important role in 
providing economic transportation, these constraints will need to be removed. The Government 
of the PRC has therefore adopted an aggressive plan to improve the railways, and has planned 
network expansion and capacity enhancements in underserved areas.

2  Between 1978 and 2007, gross domestic product (GDP) increased 67.5 times, the length of road grew 3 times, and

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
 
1.  Government Strategy 
 
5.  The government’s railway development policy puts emphasis on (i) removing constraints 
and expanding the system, (ii) encouraging the construction of joint venture and local railways 
to promote the development of local economies, (iii) improving the efficiency and safety of the 
existing  system  by  using  new  technology  and  modern  management  tools  in  planning  and 
operation, (iv) reducing operating subsidies through appropriate pricing and commercialization 
of  services,  (v)  initiating  institutional  and  structural  reforms  to  increase  autonomy  and 
accountability, and (vi) encouraging nongovernment investment in infrastructure and related 
services.  
 
6.  In 2004, the State Council approved a railway development plan for the period up to 
2020, which was updated in 2008. The plan seeks to expand the railway network to 120,000 km 
by 2020. Increasing train speed is a major goal. Priority will be given to the development of 
railways in unserved areas and regions that lack transport and have remained less developed. 
Route network length in the western region of the PRC will increase by 16,000 km–40,000 km 
by 2020. To improve operating efficiency, MOR has begun to separate passenger and freight 
trains on key rail corridors.3  
 
7.  The Eleventh Five-Year Plan (11th FYP), 2006–2010, highlights railway development 
and accelerated railway construction. It foresees (i) the construction of 17,000 km of new lines 
for a total network length of 92,000 route-km, and (ii) the conversion of 45% of the network 
length into double-track electrified railway. The plan seeks to (i) build a dedicated passenger 
railway network through the construction of 7,000 km of passenger-dedicated lines by 2010; 
(ii) develop coal transport corridors by increasing the capacity of the existing lines; (iii) expand 
the railway network in the poor western region (to 34,000 km); (iv) build international corridors at 
the  southwest  and  northwest  borders;  and  (v)  develop  a  nationwide  intermodal  container 
network.  A  total  investment  of  CNY1.5  trillion  (about  $200 billion)—CNY1.25  trillion  for 
construction and CNY250 billion for rolling stock—is planned in the 11th FYP, of which a total of 
CNY765.2 billion has been spent in 2006, 2007, and 2008 (Appendix 3). 
 
8.  In  view  of  the  downturn  in  the  international  economy,  the  government  adopted  an 
aggressive plan to boost internal demand and consumption, and declared a stimulus package in 
October 2008. The stimulus package emphasizes railway development. For 2009–2012, a total 
investment of CNY1.5 trillion is envisaged for railway development in poor, unserved areas—
particularly  in  the  western  region. 4 These  investments  would  include  new  construction, 
upgrading of existing lines, double tracking, electrification, and upgrading and building new 
terminals. Given this background, the government requested the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) to provide an investment program to support railway development in the less developed 
southwestern region.5 ADB proposes to provide this support by use of the MFF modality, which 
will be used for the first time in the PRC transport sector.

2.  ADB’s Strategy, Sector Experience, and Development Coordination 
 
9.  The ADB strategy for the railway sector is centered on helping (i) expand the railway 
system by constructing new lines in unserved and less developed areas, (ii) modernize railways 
and increase safety and capacity to improve efficiency on key routes, (iii) promote energy 
conservation and environmental sustainability, (iv) commercialize railway operations to sustain 
efficient operations, and (v) increase railway competitiveness in the transport sector through 
restructuring and reform. ADB, the lead development partner in the PRC railway sector, is 
supporting the development of railways in poor, less developed inland provinces to promote 
sustainable economic growth and reduce poverty.6 ADB has provided 17 loans totaling about 
$3.5 billion to finance the construction of about 1,921 km of eight provincial railways operated by 
joint ventures with MOR, 6,620 km of new railway lines under the eight national railway projects, 
and a sector-wide intervention to improve safety on the PRC railway network. ADB assistance 
to the sector has evolved from financing civil works on local railways to supporting major 
national corridors with much less financing but with safety, management information system, 
environmental, and other technological improvements. The investment program, designed to 
promote economic growth by providing railway transportation in underserved, less developed, 
and poor areas of the southwestern PRC, is consistent with PRC’s development priorities and 
the ADB strategy. 
 
10.  In the railway subsector, the Japan Bank for International Cooperation and the World 
Bank, in addition to the ADB, have been mainly involved in expanding the capacity of national 
railways.  In  the  past  20  years,  the  Japan  Bank  for  International  Cooperation  has  provided 
¥578 billion for 15 railway projects to expand rail transport capacity, particularly in major coal 
transport corridors. It has also financed the development of new sections of the national railway 
network  in  inland  provinces.  Since  1984,  the  World  Bank  has  provided  13  loans  totaling 
$3.2 billion for 12 national railway projects and one local railway project (Appendix 5). ADB 
introduced  Agence  Française  de  Développement  (AFD)  in  2004  to  the  PRC  railway  and 
cofinanced a railway project in Yunnan. AFD provided another loan of Euro 80 million in 2005 for 
network expansion. Kreditanstalt für Wiederaufbau (KfW) has provided 6 loans for Euro 604 
million and US$80 million since 2005. Austria has provided a loan of Euro 30 million in 2006 and 
Spain provided a loan for Euro 80 million in 2005. US Export Import Bank has provided two loans 
of $300 million for procurement of track equipment since 2003. ADB has coordinated closely with 
other development partners on policy dialogue and shared its development experiences with 
them. 
 
3.  Policy Dialogue 
 
11.  Policy dialogue has been a feature of ADB assistance to the railway sector and has 
effectively complemented lending operations. Since 2002, ADB has actively engaged MOR, the 
National Development and Reform Commission, and the Ministry of Finance in policy dialogue 
and  discussion;  and  has  reached  broad  agreement  on  reforms  as  an  engine  for  further 
development of the railways. The railway development plan defines the major goals for the PRC 
railways to 2020, and conforms with the strategic agenda of ADB. MOR’s proposed reform 
agenda under this plan involves (i) studying and learning from the best international practices, 
(ii) separating core operations from noncore transportation businesses, (iii) streamlining the staff, 
(iv) reforming the railway investment and financing system, and (v) establishing specialized 
transportation companies.

c.  Enhancing Safety 
16.  Safety  is  an  integral  part  of  providing  competitive,  high  quality,  and  reliable 
transportation  for  people  and  goods.  As  PRC  railways  have  modernized,  introduced  new 
concepts and technologies and increased speeds, safety needs have changed. The 11th FYP of 
MOR (2006–2010) recognizes this important aspect and seeks to promote integrated safety 
management, information network security, and an emergency management system consistent 
with the development needs of the PRC railways. It seeks to attract foreign technology and 
expertise  to  meet  these  needs.  ADB  policy  dialogue  with  MOR  emphasizes  the  need  for 
operational reforms for the rail network, including enhancing safety in construction, operation, 
and maintenance. MOR and ADB support the safety and security objective on PRC railways 
through introduction of modern technologies, policy development, legislation, monitoring, and 
enforcement and outreach activities (Appendix 6). Since 2003, ADB has supported investments 
in  railway  safety  as  part  of  ADB  financing,  and  has  worked  closely  with  the  safety  and 
transportation  departments  of  MOR  to  develop  a  comprehensive  plan  on  the  institutional 
investment  and  training  needs  for  safety  in  PRC  railways.  ADB  also  initiated  dialogue  on 
adopting a sector-wide approach on safety rather than a project-based approach. Adopting a 
sector-wide approach is consistent with the network approach adopted for railway operations in 
the PRC; and helps in providing economies of scale and better management of emergencies, 
preventive maintenance, and accidents.

government  and  MOR  requested  ADB  assistance  in  researching  and  learning  from  best 
international practices on an emergency management system in advanced railway systems in

d.  Sector Reforms 
18.  ADB is supporting the institutional reform of the railway sector to separate government 
and enterprise functions, giving full play to market forces and increasing the competitiveness of 
the railways. ADB has actively pursued (i) the separation of the core transport business from the 
noncore transport business, (ii) the segmentation of passenger and freight services, and (iii) the 
strengthening of the recently corporatized  specialized transportation companies. As part of 
ADB’s policy dialogue with MOR, three large companies handling containers, special goods, 
and express parcel have been set up.13 The establishment of passenger-dedicated corridors 
with  a  separate  institutional  structure  is  a  key  ADB  intervention.14 With  ADB  assistance, 
institutional, marketing, business development, and technical standards have been worked out 
for such initiatives; and capacity-building support was provided to officials of MOR.15 
 
19.  The streamlining of transportation and non-transportation staff is also being pursued. On 
18  March  2005,  under  a  major  restructuring  exercise,  MOR  abolished  41 sub-railway 
administration bureaus, thereby doing away with one tier of railway management. By the end of 
2008, the number of stations and sections had been reduced from 1,500 to 627. This move has 
trimmed the staff by more than 22,000 and helped rationalize operations, improve productivity, 
and  increase  efficiency.  Recent  ADB  support  for  reforms  in  operations  and  railway  safety 
includes a sector-wide intervention for the introduction of an emergency management system, 
safe  and  reliable  technology,  improved  speeds,  dedicated  passenger  and  freight  lines,  a 
modern dispatch control system, and high-quality information systems on the PRC railway 
network. The PRC’s accession to the World Trade Organization has intensified competition 
among the different modes of transport, and the structure of transport demand is likely to 
change.16 ADB advisory TA for policy reform support to MOR17 analyzed (i) the conflicting roles 
of meeting social obligations and making profits, (ii) the increasing modal competition, (iii) the 
impact of fast urbanization and economic development, and (iv) the demand for better services. 
As a lead development partner in the sector, ADB maintains close coordination with AFD, 
German development cooperation through KfW, and the World Bank; and has developed with 
these institutions a common approach to reforms and assistance (Appendix 3).

e.  Marketing and Business Development 
20.  As the PRC progresses toward a market-driven economy, its railways need to compete 
on  the  basis  of  price  and  service  quality  for  demand-based  transportation  services.  New

4.  Lessons Learned 
 
23.  The evaluation of ADB assistance for the PRC transport sector concluded that the ADB 
program for railways has been successful. 23 The evaluation noted that in the railway subsector, 
ADB strategic priorities were well aligned with PRC needs. Its overall focus of building railways 
using  modern  technologies  addressed  needs  to  increase  railway  capacity  and  reduce  the 
persistent gap between demand and supply as quickly and efficiently as possible. ADB’s priority 
of  improving  efficiency  and  commercial  orientation,  and  its  emphasis  on  restructuring  and 
reforming policy, was well matched to evolving institutional reforms in railways. Experience from 
completed and ongoing ADB-financed railway projects in the PRC shows strong commitment 
and generally satisfactory capabilities of executing agencies for project implementation. The 
speed of implementation has generally exceeded expectations at appraisal, and agencies have 
generally complied with loan covenants. Resettlement and environmental management were 
carried out satisfactorily. Audit covenants were complied with in a timely manner, and the 
audited  financial  statements  were  generally  acceptable.  Of  the  17  ADB-supported  railway 
projects, 10 have been completed and 7 are under implementation. 
 
24.  The key lessons from the completed railway projects highlight the need to (i) ensure that 
the executing agency—established for project processing, implementation, and operation—has 
adequate capacity; (ii) prepare realistic traffic forecasts; (iii) review constraints to traffic on a 
network basis, and the impact on project viability of the existing and/or planned railway lines and 
other  transportation  modes  that  may  compete  with  project  facilities;  (iv) prepare  realistic 
resettlement  projections  at  appraisal;  and  (v)  finance  railway  projects  with  appropriately 
determined debt–equity ratios. 
 
25.  Previous  railway  projects  have  contributed  to  socioeconomic  development  in  the 
projects’  influence  areas.24 The  main  impacts  are  as  follows:  (i)  new  railway  lines  in  less 
developed regions stimulated economic development, resulting in higher growth rates of gross 
domestic product (GDP) and rural incomes compared with the “without-project” scenario;25 
(ii) construction activities generated demand for unskilled labor and employment of poor workers, 
including  women,  who  would  have  otherwise  remained  unemployed  or  underemployed;26 
(iii) service roads built for construction activities opened up and benefited rural communities in 
inaccessible areas; (iv) domestic resource mobilization improved, providing additional resources 
for  social  programs27 and  generating  employment;  (v)  supply  and  transportation  of  local 
materials generated employment; (vi) improved and lower cost transport resulted in lower prices 
of agricultural inputs (such as fertilizers), which stimulated cash-crop farming and provided more 
income  to  farmers;  increased  the  mobility  of  rural  residents;  and  allowed  access  to  more 
markets, employment opportunities, and social services beyond the immediate communities; 
(vii) counties provided with new railway access recorded higher GDP growth rates than other

5.  Rationale 
 
26.  MOR will implement a plan for railway development (2009–2016) at a cost of about 
$25 billion for capacity expansion over the southwestern region of the PRC. This includes 
activities such as new construction, double tracking, electrification, and rehabilitation. Within this 
plan, one option was to support railway construction or capacity expansion as has been done in 
the  past;  and  another  option  was  to  support  targeted  areas  such  as  energy  efficiency, 
environmental sustainability, and safety, which are critically important areas for PRC railway 
sector and where ADB’s contribution could be clearly distinguished (Appendixes 6 and 7). 
Within this plan, ADB identified an investment program of $3.24 billion to support these three 
areas, for which it will provide support of $1 billion through the proposed MFF. The cost of the 
equipment is small compared to the cost of other capital assets or construction of a railway line, 
but their benefits are significant and it is easy to integrate them when the government is 
implementing  the  development  plan.  This  would  have  high  value  added  with  a  smaller 
investment, leveraging much more value addition. 
 
27.  The proposed investment program is consistent with two of the four pillars of ADB’s 
country partnership strategy of the PRC:30 (i) inclusive growth and balanced development, and 
(ii) resource efficiency and environmental sustainability. The investment program encompasses 
(i) network development, which will enhance capacity and reduce bottlenecks; (ii) improved 
energy  efficiency  and  environmental  sustainability  by  providing  a  more  efficient  and 
environment-friendly mode of transport in the region; (iii) enhanced safety through the provision 
of a reliable and safe mode of transport; (iv) support for the PRC railway development plan and 
the western region development strategy; and (v) promotion of pro-poor economic growth in the 
region, thereby reducing poverty.  
 
28.  The investment program will be implemented in the southwestern PRC, a relatively poor 
area. The region is largely mountainous with abundant natural reserves of coal, and other 
nonferrous materials; and famous tourist sites. In spite of abundant natural resources, many 
people are poor and the economic growth necessary to reduce rural poverty has failed to 
develop because of inadequate transport services and high costs. The railway density in the 
region is the lowest in the PRC, and local governments and people living in the region see the 
railway as a key investment for addressing this problem. Railway development is a part of the

29.  The investment program is a key intervention in the railway sector, with many technical,

III.  THE PROPOSED INVESTMENT PROGRAM 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
30.  The impact of the proposed investment program will be an improved transport system in 
the  region  that  supports  sustainable  socioeconomic  development  and  the  western  region 
development strategy. Providing railway transportation in underserved, less developed, and 
poor areas will create conditions for developing local resources, employment opportunities, and 
higher  incomes;  and  thus  raise  living  standards  in  the  project  area.  The  outcome  of  the

friendly  railway  transport  system  in  the  southwestern  region.  The  design  and  monitoring

B.  Outputs

environment-friendly equipment, and safety equipment; (ii) a review of the existing institutional 
arrangements  for  integrating  energy  efficiency  and  environmental  issues  in  railway 
management; (iii) conducting safety and energy audits of a nominated railway administration; 
and (iv) providing capacity building support. At an institutional level, ADB will work with MOR to 
study international best practices for integrating energy efficiency, environmental sustainability,

V.  PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
57.  The program benefits and impacts were assessed along with potential risks associated 
with the investment program. The combined benefits and impacts will outweigh the costs, and 
net benefits will accrue to the project area. 
 
A.  Economic Analysis 
58.  The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) was calculated by comparing with- and 
without-project situations, using constant 2009 economic prices. The investment program will 
introduce new and modern technology for promoting energy efficiency, improving environmental 
sustainability, and enhancing safety. Economic costs include costs for materials and equipment, 
including installation and commissioning. Economic benefits include (i) user cost savings for 
diverted freight and passenger traffic; (ii) time savings for diverted passenger and freight traffic 
from buses, trucks, and waterways; (iii) time savings for base freight and passenger traffic 
caused  by  operational  improvements;  (iv)  pollution  reduction  benefits;  (v)  energy  savings; 
(vi) avoided road infrastructure and maintenance costs; and (vii) avoided road accidents. The 
EIRR for the investment program is estimated at 26.81% (Appendix 16). Sensitivity analysis 
tested eight scenarios to assess the robustness of the results of the economic analysis. The 
initial capital cost would have to be more than 304% higher than estimated for the EIRR to fall 
below the cutoff rate of 12%. Considering the experience of ADB-financed projects in the 
railway sector, this switching value is unlikely to occur. The freight benefits would have to 
decrease more than 92% to make the investment program economically nonviable. A 1-year 
delay in completion does not affect economic viability. Combinations of adverse effects of 
benefits and costs were also tested. The results showed that the investment program would 
maintain its economic viability under plausible scenarios of variability.

implementation and financing allocation. MOR has confirmed the availability of counterpart

equipment to be procured utilizes energy-efficient technologies, which will significantly reduce 
regional greenhouse gas emission and the oil consumption. It also provides the capacity to 
respond  more  effectively  to  railway  accidents  and  natural  disasters,  thereby  limiting  any 
potential pollution resulting from these causes. 
 
D.  Social, Poverty, and Gender Aspects 
61.  The links between poverty, topography, and poor transport systems are apparent in the 
southwestern PRC. Poverty in this area is caused by (i) adverse environmental and weather 
conditions and limited farmland (e.g., mountains, cold weather, water scarcity, and soil erosion); 
(ii) geographical remoteness and isolation and high transport costs; and (iii) lack of access to 
markets, and good social and health care facilities. Providing an energy-efficient, environment-
friendly, safe, and secure transportation system enables the efficient flow of people and goods; 
conserves resources; protects the environment from pollution; and is an essential component 
for a healthy population, a high quality of life, and a prosperous economy. The investment 
program, when implemented, will help increase standards of living and reduce poverty in the 
southwestern  PRC  by  removing  a  transport  constraint  to  sustainable  economic  growth. 
Providing efficient, affordable railway transportation in underserved, less developed areas will 
create the conditions necessary for developing local resources and generating employment and 
income-enhancing opportunities. 
 
62.  The investment program will (i) reduce fuel consumption and enhance energy efficiency, 
enabling the PRC to save valuable foreign exchange, (ii) improve the environment and reduce 
pollution; (iii) enhance railway safety, enabling railway users to benefit from lower transport 
costs; (iv) increase the line capacity, benefiting consumers and producers of goods and services 
through the provision of timely and efficient transport services and lower logistics costs; and 
(v) improve staff productivity, enabling railway users to benefit from lower costs.  
 
63.  The  major  project  beneficiaries  will  be  (i)  the  government,  which  will  benefit  from 
improved safety, reduced economic losses, and a reduced energy bill; (ii) passengers, who will 
benefit from affordable, cleaner, faster, and safer trips; (iii) freight shippers, who will benefit from 
reduced damages to shipments and more affordable, faster, and safer trips; and (iv) private 
sector  who  will  benefit  from  new  business  and  job  opportunities  and  enhanced  economic 
competitiveness. The poor will benefit equally or more from the intervention. Energy-efficient, 
environment-friendly, and safe railway transport will benefit all passengers. The links between

20 
poverty and energy efficiency, environmental sustainability, and safety are apparent; and the 
poor are at a disadvantage in recovering from the physical and economic losses suffered 
because of high energy costs, poor environment, and injuries or physical loss of goods. The 
summary poverty reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 18. 
 
64.  Increased job opportunities created indirectly by railway development provide potential 
new sources of income for women. Increase in female participation in the labor and tourism 
market increases women’s net income and savings, improves overall family welfare, and helps 
improve women’s status. Women and other vulnerable groups benefit from railway development 
and have equal access to employment and wages. Railway development generates demand for 
local labor and increases worker productivity and wages. Expansion of secondary and tertiary 
industries helps generate additional employment opportunities for both men and women, close 
to their homes.  
 
E.  Risks and Assumptions 
65.  The  investment  program  is  formulated  to  minimize  potential  risks.  Sensitivity  tests 
indicate that economic circumstances would have to become substantially adverse for the 
investment program to lose economic viability. A potential risk is delay in implementation, which 
would  delay  the  realization  of  benefits.  MOR  has  successfully  implemented  ADB-financed 
projects. Risks associated with potential changes in government policy are minimal. In fact, the 
investment  program  is  an  integral  part  of  MOR’s  five-year  plan,  which  mandates  a  20% 
improvement in energy efficiency during 2006–2010, and a 10% reduction in sulphur dioxide 
emissions during 2006–2010. An analysis of the demand for railway transport shows that the 
southwestern  PRC  needs  additional  railway  transport  capacity  to  sustain  its  economic 
development. Macroeconomic conditions are expected to continue to be sound, with continuing 
political stability in the PRC. Strong economic performance is expected in the southwestern 
PRC based on the government’s projections and its growth trends. 
 
66.  The equipment and materials to be procured and included in tranche 1 are based on 
proven  and  established  technologies.  MOR  has  experience  of  installing  new  technologies 
successfully and these can be implemented within a relatively short time. For subsequent 
tranches, equipment and material with similar proven energy efficiency, environmental benefits, 
and safety benefits will be used. Thus, the technical risks of the investment program are minimal.  
 
67.  Successful implementation requires sound project and financial management. MOR has 
strong  implementation  experience  and  adequate  capacity.  The  innovative  design  of  the 
investment program will necessitate additional training, and supplemental TA support provided 
by ADB would further assist MOR in strengthening their capacities. MOR agreed to provide 
counterpart support for TA implementation. The key MOR personnel are well experienced in 
ADB project implementation.

RAILWAY SECTOR ANALYSIS AND ROAD MAP 
 
A.  Railway Sector Profile 
 
1.  Key features. Despite government efforts to increase the country’s transport capacity, 
serious constraints and bottlenecks remain, especially in the road and railway sectors. By the 
end of 2008, the People’s Republic of China (PRC) railway system of 79,700 kilometers (km) 
comprised 64,000 km of national railways and 15,700 km of joint venture and local railways. 
From  1978,  when  economic  reforms  were  first  introduced,  through  to  2008,  the  PRC 
experienced sustained rapid economic growth. This resulted in a correspondingly rapid increase 
in demand for transportation. Passenger transport grew by 9% yearly and freight transport by 
7.6% yearly during the period. Railways are the principal mode of freight transport in the PRC, 
accounting for 45.2% of total freight ton-km in 2008, followed by 29.6% for inland waterways 
and seashore shipping, 21.1% for roads, 3.3% for pipelines, and 0.2% for civil aviation. Road 
traffic accounted for 53.3% of total passenger-km, followed by railways with 33.4%, civil aviation 
with 12.9%, and coastal and inland waterways with 3.5%.  
 
2.  Recent  developments.  To  minimize  transport  inefficiencies  and  eliminate  transport 
bottlenecks  that  constrain  efficient  economic  development,  the  Government  of  the  PRC 
increased its investment in transport infrastructure in the Tenth Five-Year Plan, 2001–2005, and 
the Eleventh Five-Year Plan (11th FYP), 2006–2010. Investment in transport infrastructure as a 
share of gross domestic product (GDP) has more than doubled in the last decade. The PRC had 
invested CNY308 billion in capital construction to build 6,458 km of new lines, provide 3,275 km 
of double lines, and electrify 6,259 km of tracks in the Tenth Five-Year Plan. A World Bank 
study1 indicates that total transport investment should increase to at least 3.8% of GDP to avoid 
the economic costs associated with transport constraints. The government continues to accord 
high priority to transport infrastructure investments to meet the increase in transport demand. 
 
3.  Future development priorities and outlook. Substantial investments in the road and 
railway sectors from both domestic and international financing sources, including the private 
sector, are envisaged in the 11th FYP. The plan continues to emphasize railway development, 
and seeks to accelerate railway construction. It envisages (i) the construction of 17,000 km of 
new lines, and (ii) the double tracking and electrification of 45% of the network length. The plan 
seeks  to  (i)  build  a  dedicated  passenger  railway  network  by  constructing  7,000 km  of 
passenger-dedicated  lines  by  2010;  (ii)  develop  coal  transport  corridors  by  increasing  the 
capacity of the existing lines; (iii) expand the railway network in the poor western region (to 
34,000 km); (iv) build international corridors at the southwest and northwest borders; and (v) 
develop a nationwide intermodal container network. A total investment of CNY1.5 trillion, or 
about $200 billion (CNY1.25 trillion for construction and CNY250 billion for rolling stock) is 
planned in the 11th FYP, of which a total of CNY765.2 billion has been spent in 2006, 2007, and 
2008.

western region of the PRC by 2020. The plan also calls for separating passenger and freight

C.  ADB Strategy 
 
8.  Strategy  and  priorities.  ADB’s  strategy  for  the  railway  sector  has  three  broad 
objectives:  (i) improve  economic  efficiency,  (ii) promote  growth  in  poor  inland  provinces  to 
reduce poverty, and (iii) protect the environment and manage natural resources. In pursuit of 
these  three  objectives,  the  strategy  supports  the  development  of  efficient  and  integrated 
transport  networks  to meet  the  needs  of  a growing  market  economy  and  to  contribute  to 
reducing poverty through investment targeting poorer areas, coupled with policy and institutional 
reforms. Because of the importance of railway transport for the development of the national 
economy, ADB’s strategy for the railway sector is focused on (i) expanding the railway system 
by constructing new lines in unserved areas that are less developed and poor, (ii) modernizing 
and increasing safety and capacity to improve transport efficiency of the national railway system, 
(iii) promoting  energy  conservation  and  environmental  sustainability,  (iv)  commercializing 
railway operations to sustain efficient operations, and (v) increasing railway competitiveness in 
the transport system through restructuring and reform.  
 
9.  Poverty reduction. To heighten the poverty reduction impact of transport investments, 
ADB  pays  particular  attention  to  four  issues:  (i) locating  ADB-financed  projects  in  less 
developed  and  poor  regions  where  new  lines  will  stimulate  economic  development, 
(ii) encouraging the maximization of employment of poor people during project construction and 
operation, (iii) supplying local materials that meet the requirements of quality and economy from

MANAGEMENT OF RAILWAY SAFETY 
 
1.  Managing safety is an important aspect of reliable transportation and critical to providing 
a competitive, high quality, and safe mode of transport to people and goods. The People’s 
Republic of China (PRC), a country with diverse geology and a challenging environment, has 
two-thirds of its area threatened by floods, nearly half of the cities located in the seismic belt, 
more mountainous areas than plain areas, great elevation differences between east and west, 
frequent geological disasters such as landslides and flow of debris, frequent typhoons in the 
southern part, frequent sandstorms and windstorms in the western part, and snowstorms in the 
northern part. PRC railways crisscross the length and breadth of the country, and this working 
environment makes managing safety on the PRC railways a technical and human challenge.  
 
2.  The  Government  of  the  PRC  and  the  Ministry  of  Railways  (MOR)  attach  great 
importance to rail transport safety, and it is an important cornerstone of the PRC railway 
development strategy. Safety is an inherent element underlying all planned modernization and 
technological upgrading on PRC railways. It is supported through various development plans, 
such as the five-year plans, annual development plans, and the long-term railway network 
development plan 2020, which include strategy and investments in the important area of railway 
safety.  
 
3.  The  railway  development  plan,  which  lays  down  an  ambitious  blueprint  of  railway 
network  development  until  2020,  envisages  that  safety  of  rail  transport  services  shall  be 
ensured by (i) strictly adhering to safety regulations, (ii) improving staff education and technical 
skills  through  training,  (iii)  upgrading  technology  and  modernizing  equipment  for  railway 
operation and safety, and (iv) strengthening responsibility and accountability for safety in railway 
transport. 
 
4.  The plan also envisages that information technology and computerization will cover all 
facets of railway operation and management—particularly transport safety and operations. It 
also recognizes that expansion of the railway network and technological upgrading have not 
been accompanied by investments and development in human resources, and seeks to provide 
impetus by increased investment support. MOR has adopted a proactive strategy for safety 
management and adopted initiatives that cover technology, equipment, and human resource 
development through training and education under the Eleventh Five-Year Plan.  
 
5.  PRC  railways  have  a  well-established  three-level  organizational  structure  (ministry, 
railway administration, and station) for the management of safety on the railways (Figure A6.1).  
 
6.  Within MOR, the supervision of safety is the responsibility of the Safety Supervision 
Bureau (SSB), which has three divisions. SSB is headed by a director general, and has the 
following responsibilities: 
 
(i)  supervise the execution by railway administrations and related departments of 
the directions, policies, laws, regulations, and instructions on safety of production 
issued by the state; 
(ii)  supervise  the  implementation  of  regulations,  acts,  and  measures  relating  to 
operational safety, non-railway personnel safety, and accident treatment; 
(iii)  supervise maintenance and repair, and periodical repair of all train operation 
equipment;

involved in train operation; urge the relevant department and unit to take effective

MANAGEMENT OF ENERGY EFFICIENCY AND ENVIRONMENTAL SUSTAINABILITY 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  Enhancing energy efficiency and promoting environmental sustainability are critically 
important for the People’s Republic of China (PRC) transportation sector. The PRC has the 
second highest energy consumption in the world, next only to the United States, and the 
consumption is growing at a high rate. In 2007, the PRC consumed 2.65 billion equivalent coal 
tons,  an  increase  of  almost  100%  compared  to  1.39  billion  tons  equivalent  coal  in  2000 
(Table A7). Energy consumption in the PRC is expected to grow at 8% annually up to 2020.  
 
2.  The PRC has limited energy resources and is therefore dependent on imports to meet 
the domestic demand, particularly petroleum products. It is one of the largest importers of 
petroleum and volumes of imports have been growing at a steady pace. In 2007, the PRC 
imported 163 million tons of petroleum compared to 70 million in 2000, an annual increase of 
12.8% (Table A7).

3.  The Government of the PRC and the Ministry of Railways (MOR) attach high importance 
to energy conservation and environmental sustainability in the PRC railway sector, and have 
included energy efficiency and environmental sustainability as key priorities in the Eleventh 
Five-Year Plan (11th FYP). MOR highlights energy efficiency and environmental sustainability as 
essential elements underlying all planed modernization and technological upgrading on PRC 
railways. This is supported through various development plans, such as the long-term railway 
network  development  plan  (2020),  five-year  plans,  annual  development  plans,  and  energy 
saving and environmental protection annual plans. 
 
4.  The long-term railway network development plan lays down an ambitious blueprint of 
railway network development until 2020. It envisages that energy efficiency and environmental 
sustainability in the railway sector shall be achieved by (i) strictly complying with energy saving 
and environmental protection regulations, and accomplishing the indicators of energy saving 
and environmental protection; (ii) upgrading technology and modernizing equipment for railway 
operation, and promoting application of advanced energy-efficient and environmental equipment; 
(iii) enhancing management of energy efficiency and reducing emissions; (iv) improving staff 
professional knowledge and technical skills, and fostering staff awareness of energy saving and 
environmental sustainability; and (v) encouraging and spreading the adoption of new energy 
and renewable energy.

6.  At MOR level, the supervision of energy efficiency and environmental sustainability is the 
responsibility of the Energy Conservation and Environmental Protection Division (ESCPD) in the 
Development and Planning Department. ESCPD is headed by a director, supervised by a 
deputy director general and a director general, and has the following main responsibilities: 
 
(i)  prepare the regulations of energy conservation, environmental sustainability, and 
resource utilization in the railway sector; 
(ii)  prepare railway conservation and environmental mid-long term development plan, 
energy conservation annual plan for railway entities, annual plan for controlling 
emission and pollution; and issue the status and indicators bulletin of energy 
conservation and emission reduction; 
(iii)  organize  review  of  environmental  impact  assessment  reports  of  large  and 
medium size railway construction projects; appraise design documents of the 
large and medium construction projects and conduct acceptability examination 
for completed projects; 
(iv)  supervise the execution by railway administrations and related departments of 
the directions, policies, laws, regulations, and instructions on energy efficiency 
and environmental sustainability issued by the state; 
(v)  supervise  the  implementation  of  regulations,  acts,  and  measures  relating  to 
operational energy efficiency and environmental sustainability; 
(vi)  direct and supervise the treatment of railway environmental pollution accidents; 
and 
(vii)  advertise  national  and  MOR  policies  of  energy  efficiency  and  environmental 
sustainability; educate the energy and environmental staff of MOR. 
 
7.  The staff of ESCPD has expertise in railway operation, energy efficiency, environmental 
engineering, and transportation.  
 
8.  The second level of energy efficiency and environmental sustainability management is at 
the railway administration level. At railway administration level, an Energy Conservation and 
Environmental Protection Office (ESCPO) is set up to coordinate and undertake actions for 
energy efficiency and environmental sustainability. The ESCPO has dual reporting functions; it 
reports to the director general of the railway administration and submits direct reports to ESCPD. 
ESCPOs monitor and supervise the energy efficiency and environmental sustainability functions 
at the railway administration level. 
 
9.  ESCPOs at the railway administration level have the following main responsibilities: 
 
(i)  carry out the state and ministry regulations and laws related to energy saving and 
environmental  sustainability  and  local  government’s  energy  saving  and 
environmental  rules,  prepare  railway  administration’s  operational  and 
management  rules  of  energy  saving  and  the  environment  based  on  the 
regulations and policies above; 
(ii)  prepare railway administration’s annual plan of energy saving and environmental 
protection indicators, update annual plan, and organize their implementation; 
(iii)  organize  the  environmental  impact  assessment  and  prepare  soil  erosion 
prevention plan of construction projects; 
(iv)  monitor and supervise the implementation of environmental mitigating measures 
of railway construction projects in their jurisdiction; 
(v)  mitigate environmental pollution;

(vii)  prepare  the  emergency  plan  on  environmental  accidents  and  respond  to

(viii)  coordinate and resolve environmental dissensions, and receive complaints from

10.  The third level of energy efficiency and environmental sustainability management is at 
the field level and includes two kinds of units: (i) an independent environmental protection 
monitoring station, and (ii) an energy conservation and environmental protection unit. 
 
11.  Each  railway  administration  has  three  to  five  environmental  protection  monitoring 
stations,1 depending on the size and scale of the area. It has about eight to 12 environmental 
professional  and  technical  staff,  and  is  equipped  with  special  environmental  monitoring 
equipment and inspecting instruments. 
 
12.  The environmental protection monitoring station has the following functions: 
 
(i)  inspect  periodically  the  indicators  of  noise,  water,  gas,  and  radiation  of 
electromagnetism from the environmental sensitive spots, and provide quarterly 
monitoring reports to railway administrations; 
(ii)  monitor and supervise the operation of environmental equipment; 
(iii)  participate in the investigation of accidents in accordance with the regulations for 
the treatment of environmental accidents and provide quantitative analyses on 
the accidents; 
(iv)  provide technical training and professional education regularly for staff in the 
railway administration; and 
(v)  assist MOR and the railway administration to conduct a periodic environmental 
examination. 
 
13.  Energy conservation and environmental protection units are located in every station and 
depot,2 and each unit has one to five experienced staff. Their functions are as follows: 
 
(i)  carry out the MOR and railway administration regulations on energy saving and 
environmental sustainability; 
(ii)  report  indicators  of  energy  saving  and  environmental  protection,  and  update 
annual plan of stations and depots; 
(iii)  operate, manage, and maintain the energy saving and environmental equipment 
in the stations and depots; 
(iv)  implement  the  annual  plan  of  station  energy  saving  and  environmental 
sustainability,  enhance  energy  saving  and  ensure  the  implementation  of 
environmental mitigating measures; 
(v)  conduct  data  collection  of  statistical  information  on  energy  saving  and 
environmental protection, and analyze status of energy saving and environmental 
sustainability;

14.  The above organization structure for management and monitoring energy efficiency and 
environmental sustainability has worked well. Every year, MOR organizes an annual meeting to 
discuss achievements in railway energy efficiency and environmental protection. The meeting 
reviews the progress made and discusses the targets and plan for the next year. A mid-year 
meeting is also held to take stock of the progress achieved in the first 6 months and necessary 
adjustments are made to achieve the annual targets. Annual training sessions are organized for 
the staff working in energy conservation and environmental offices as well as related institutes 
every year. Each railway administration also organizes one or two training sessions for the staff 
from the stations and depots. 
 
C.  Targets and Actions 
 
15.  MOR  has  set  measurable  targets  for  energy  conservation  and  environmental 
sustainability for the 11th FYP, 2006–2010. In comparison to 2005, by 2010 the plan seeks the 
following reductions: (i) energy consumption per unit revenue reduced by 20%; (ii) fresh water 
usage  per  unit  revenue  reduced  by  10%;  (iii)  chemical  oxygen  demand  per  unit  revenue 
reduced by 10%; and (iv) sulfur dioxide emission reduced by 10%.  
 
16.  MOR  attaches  high  importance  to  achieving  these  targets.  It  has  taken  steps  for 
controlling energy consumption, reducing pollution emission, and creating awareness; and has 
instituted systems for monitoring and management of entities at the three levels. Introducing 
new products, new technologies and expertise, new methods of investment, and clean energy 
such as geothermal energy are areas where some progress has been made. MOR plans to 
undertake innovation in maintenance and sulfur dioxide treatment to achieve targets of the 11th 
FYP.  In  addition,  MOR  plans  to  strengthen  transportation  and  organization  management, 
optimize asset and rolling stock utilization, improve equipment quality, enhance driving skills 
and techniques, and achieve higher operational efficiencies. MOR also seeks to enhance the 
outreach activities and create awareness about energy conservation measures to the traveling 
public and MOR employees.

A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The impact of the proposed investment program will be an improved transport system in

and higher incomes; and thus raise living standards in the project area. The outcome of the 
investment program will be an energy-efficient, safe, reliable, affordable, and environment-
friendly railway transport system in the southwestern region. The investment program comprises 
(i) the introduction of energy-efficient technologies, environment-friendly equipment, and safety 
equipment;  (ii)  a  review  of  the  existing  institutional  arrangements  for  integrating  energy 
efficiency and environmental issues in railway management; (iii) conducting safety and energy 
audits of a nominated railway administration; and (iv) providing capacity building support.

A.  Traffic Forecast 
 
1.  Since the Railway Energy Efficiency and Safety Enhancement Investment Program will 
support the entire railway network of the southwestern People’s Republic of China (PRC), its 
analysis requires assessment of system-wide traffic forecasts for passengers and freight over 
the  20-year  (2016–2035)  evaluation  period.  Rail  traffic  for  the  southwestern  region,  which 
comprises  four  provinces  (Guangxi,  Guizhou,  Sichuan,  and  Yunnan)  and  Chongqing 
Municipality, was forecast for freight and passengers in two categories differentiated by their 
economic impact: (i) base (normal) traffic that will benefit from improved operational efficiency, 
represented by an increase in the average speed of freight and passenger trains as a result of 
the new technologies introduced by the investment program; and (ii) freight traffic diverted from 
roads and waterways, and passenger traffic diverted from roads as a result of additional line 
capacity  available  in  the  southwestern  region  railway  network  as  a  result  of  the  new 
technologies introduced by the investment program. The traffic forecast was based on a two-tier

B.   Economic Evaluation

telecommunication system equipment, intelligent power supply system for signaling, overhead 
catenary and traction substation systems, electric power supply equipment, noise barriers, 
infrared hot box detection system, and track car sets. The with-project scenario is based on the 
improved  response  and  restoration  times  resulting  from  the  proposed  investment  program 
compared to current response and restoration capabilities.

equipment, non-tradable materials, labor, and land. The prices were expressed in yuan (CNY) 
using the domestic price numeraire with a shadow exchange rate factor of 1.01 for foreign 
exchange effects. A shadow wage rate factor of 0.67 was used to put an economic value on the 
wages paid to unskilled labor, but not on wages for skilled labor since no clear surplus of skilled 
workers exists. 
 
11.  Benefits.  Economic  benefits  include  (i)  user  cost  savings  for  diverted  freight  and 
passenger traffic; (ii) time savings for diverted passenger and freight traffic from buses, trucks, 
and waterways; (iii) time savings for base freight and passenger traffic resulting from operational 
improvements;  (iv)  pollution  reduction  benefits;  (v)  energy  savings;  (vi)  avoided  road 
infrastructure and maintenance costs; and (vii) avoided road accidents.  
 
12.  For diverted passenger traffic from road (5.69 billion passenger-km in 2016), the user 
cost saving (CNY270.41 million in 2016) is the difference in the passenger economic fare 
between road and rail transport (CNY0.0475 per passenger-km). Passenger traffic time savings 
(CNY227.14  million  in  2016)  are  computed  for  base  and  diverted  traffic  (160.18  billion 
passenger-km in 2016). Time savings are due to the response and restoration time of safety 
equipment, which is estimated at 4.61 hours per incident for estimated 70 incidents in 2016 
(73 in 2020, 85 in 2035). New safety equipment included in the investment program allows 
faster  response  time  to  accidents  and  shorter  time  to  clear  the  track  under  with-project 
conditions. When additional track access is provided, line capacity is increased, allowing the 
railway to move more freight and passenger trains through the network. This is the diverted 
traffic  under  with-project  conditions,  which  is  multiplied  by  the  economic  price  difference 
between rail and road transport to estimate safety enhancement benefits. In addition, safety 
enhancement benefits include time savings to passengers and freight as a result of faster 
transport under with-project conditions. 
 
13.  For  freight traffic  diverted  from  trucks  (15.24 billion  ton-km  in  2016),  the  economic 
benefit (CNY1.75 billion in 2016) is the difference in shipper economic costs between truck and 
rail  transport  (CNY0.115  per  ton-km).  For  freight  traffic  diverted  from  inland  waterway 
(3.81 billion ton-km in 2016), the economic benefit (CNY–45.73 million in 2016) is the difference 
in shipper economic costs between inland waterway and rail transport (CNY–0.012 per ton-km). 
For freight time savings benefit (CNY2.90 billion in 2016), an adjusted economic value added

petroleum  products,  steel,  and  grains)  to  CNY16,063  per  ton  for  containerized cargo  was 
computed based on current financial value, non-tax elements, and shadow exchange rate 
factor. The adjusted economic values per ton represent the net economic value, i.e., the value 
of output at economic prices less the costs of production (sum of all intermediate input costs, 
wages, and annualized investment costs).

from CNY34.46 million in 2017 to CNY69.36 million in 2035 to accommodate increased traffic

A.  Introduction 
 
1.  This safeguards framework was prepared for the proposed Railway Energy Efficiency 
and  Safety  Enhancement  Investment  Program  (the  Investment  Program)  in  the  People’s

(iii)  conducting  safety  and  energy  audits  of  a  nominated  railway  administration;  and

1.  Key Issues  
 
The links between poverty, topography, and poor transport systems are apparent in the southwestern PRC. Poverty in this 
area is caused by adverse environmental and weather conditions and limited farmland (e.g., mountains, cold weather, water 
scarcity, and soil erosion); geographical remoteness and isolation and high transport costs; and lack of access to markets, 
good education, and health care facilities. Railway network development has direct and indirect impacts for poor families to 
(i) move away from unsustainable, mountainous farmlands; (ii) have better access to markets, and advanced educational and 
health facilities, especially for women; and (iii) build a sustainable future in centers of economic activity. 
 
2.  Design Features  
The investment program will be implemented in the southwestern PRC, a relatively poor area. The region is largely 
mountainous with abundant natural reserves of coal, and other nonferrous materials; and famous tourist sites. In spite of 
abundant natural resources, many people are poor and the economic growth necessary to reduce rural poverty has failed to 
develop because of inadequate transport services and high costs. The railway density is the lowest in the region and local 
governments and people living in the region see the railway as a key investment for addressing this problem. Railway 
development is part of the government’s program for the integrated development of transportation facilities in this poor region 
and the Ministry of Railways (MOR) plans to develop 6,500 kilometers (km) of railways in the region by 2015. The proposed 
region also shares borders with Viet Nam, and Yunnan and Guangxi provinces are part of the Greater Mekong Subregion. 
The development of railways is expected to play an important role in facilitating and integrating this poor and underdeveloped 
region, and stimulating regional and interprovincial trade and movement of people. The investment program is a priority 
investment included in the government’s proposed Eleventh Five-Year Plan and the stimulus package announced in October 
2008.
